prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CRL618: HCCCN 25-24, v7='0,1,2,3,4,5 v6=0,1,2,3, v5=01,2,3 v4=0,1, v3=0,1 + CN N=2-1+ CO J=2-1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Single point position with frequency setup covering the J=25-24 line of HCCCN in all vibrational states below 1000 cm-1. As bonus CN and CO will be also observed. CN will trace directly the photodissociation regions of the envelope (innermost and external layers). CO will provide the highest angular resolution view of the gas around the central object, the bipolar outflow and the torus.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The expected line intensity in a beam of 0.18" is 3000-4000 times that observed with the 30m at the same frequency (beam 11") depending on the molecular transition. Hence, brightness temperatures of several tens to hundreds K are expected with ALMA from the dense PDR of CRL618. The longest spatial scales will correspond to those of the ground state of the molecules covered in the proposed frequency bands. The requested sensitivity will permit to achieve a high S/N in all physical components of CRL618.

The requested spectral resolution of 1 km/s will permit to resolve the different regions of the envelope of CRL618 (outflow 100-400 km/s, warm expanding envelope 10-40 km/s, and the lines from the photodissociation region 5-10 km/s). Spectral averaging can not performed at data acquistion without degrading the science goals related to the study of the PDR. For the other regions of the envelope the data will be averaged after processing to a resolution of 2-3 km/s (warm expanding envelope) to 5-10 km/s for the outflow to increase the sensitivity of the observations.
We have selected a spectral average of 2 to reduce the data rate.

The central PDR has a size <1" in radius. The continuum source has a radius of 0.2-0.3". The warm region around the PDR has a size of 2-3" and the outflow extends over 5". The selected angular resolution of 0.18" is a good compromise to fully characterize the warm gas around CRL618. Extended emission is present in CO and we required an additional compact configuration to obtain larger spatial structures (outflows).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CRL618: CCH N=3-2 HCCCN J=29-28 HCN J=3-2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Single point position with frequency setup covering the J=29-28 line of HCCCN in all vibrational states below 1000 cm-1. CCH N=3-2 and HCN J=3-2 will be also observed. CCH N=3-2 will trace directly the photodissociation region of acetylene in the envelope (innermost and external layers). HCN will provide the highest angular resolution view of the dense gas around the central object, the bipolar outflow and the central torus.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The expected line intensity in a beam of .18" is 3000-4000 times that observed with the 30m at the same frequency (beam 11") depending on the molecular transition. Hence, brightness temperatures of several tens to hundreds K are expected with ALMA from the dense PDR of CRL618. The longest spatial scales will correspond to those of the ground state of the molecules covered in the proposed frequency bands. The requested sensitivity will permit to achieve a high S/N in all physical components of CRL618.

The requested spectral resolution of 1 km/s will permit to resolve the different regions of the envelope of CRL618 (outflow 100-400 km/s, warm expanding envelope 10-40 km/s, and the lines from the photodissociation region 5-10 km/s). Spectral averaging can not performed at data acquistion without degrading the science goals related to the study of the PDR. For the other regions of the envelope the data will be averaged after processing to a resolution of 2-3 km/s (warm expanding envelope) to 5-10 km/s for the outflow to increase the sensitivity of the observations.
We have selected a spectral average of 2 to reduce the data rate.

The central PDR has a size <1" in radius. The continuum source has a radius of 0.2-0.3". The warm region around the PDR has a size of 2-3" and the outflow extends over 5". The selected angular resolution of 0.18" is a good compromise to fully characterize the warm gas around CRL618. Extended emission is present in CO but corresponding to the remnant cold envelope created during the AGB phase of the star.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CRL618: HNC & HCO+ 3-2 + H29a + HC3N 28-27
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Single point position with frequency setup covering the J=3-2 lines of HNC and HCO+ J=3-2. In the lower band H29a and the J=28-27 line of HCCCN in all vibrational states below 1000 cm-1 will be also observed. HCO+ will trace the ion-neutral chemistry while HNC will be a primary tracer of photochemistry and ion-neutral reactions. HCCCN will trace mainly the photochemistry of the dense gas. H29a will trace the inner and dense HII region (size 0.5") placed in the middle of the central torus.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The expected line intensity in a beam of .18" is 3000-4000 times that observed with the 30m at The expected line intensity in a beam of .18" is 3000-4000 times that observed with the 30m at the same frequency (beam 11") depending on the molecular transition. Hence, brightness temperatures of several tens to hundreds K are expected with ALMA from the dense PDR of CRL618. The longest spatial scales will correspond to those of the ground state of the molecules covered in the proposed frequency bands. The requested sensitivity will permit to achieve a high S/N in all physical components of CRL618.

The requested spectral resolution of 1 km/s will permit to resolve the different regions of the envelope of CRL618 (outflow 100-400 km/s, warm expanding envelope 10-40 km/s, and the lines from the photodissociation region 5-10 km/s). Spectral averaging can not performed at data acquistion without degrading the science goals related to the study of the PDR. For the other regions of the envelope the data will be averaged after processing to a resolution of 2-3 km/s (warm expanding envelope) to 5-10 km/s for the outflow to increase the sensitivity of the observations.

The continuous frequency coverage is necessary to cover as many lines of HCCCN vibrationally excited as possible. Hence, the required data rate is justified scientifically. HNC and HCO+ will trace the photodissociation region, the high velocity outflow, and the inner structure of the central torus.
We have selected a spectral average of 2 to reduce the data rate.

The central PDR has a size <1" in radius. The continuum source has a radius of 0.2-0.3". The warm region around the PDR has a size of 2-3" and the outflow extends over 5". The selected angular resolution of 0.18" is a good compromise to fully characterize the warm gas around CRL618. Extended emission is present in CO but corresponding to the remnant cold envelope created during the AGB phase of the star.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CRL2688: HCCCN 25-24, v7='0,1,2,3,4,5 v6=0,1,2,3, v5=01,2,3 v4=0,1, v3=0,1 + CN N=2-1+ CO J=2-1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Single point position with frequency setup covering the J=25-24 line of HCCCN in all vibrational states below 1000 cm-1. As bonus CN and CO will be also observed. CN will trace directly the photodissociation regions of the envelope (innermost and external layers). CO will provide the highest angular resolution view of the gas around the central object, the bipolar outflow and the torus.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The expected line intensity in a beam of .18" is 3000-4000 times that observed with the 30m at the same frequency (beam 11"). Hence, brightness temperatures of several tens to hundreds K are expected with ALMA from the dense internal region of CRL2688 depending on the molecular transition. The longest spatial scales will correspond to those of the ground state of the molecules covered in the proposed band coverage.

The requested spectral resolution of 1 km/s will permit to resolve the different regions of the envelope of CRL2688 (outflow 100-400 km/s, warm expanding envelope 10-40 km/s, and the lines from the central torus region 5-10 km/s). Spectral averaging can not performed at data acquistion without degrading the science goals related to the study of the torus. For the other regions of the envelope the data will be averaged after processing to a resolution of 2 km/s (warm expanding envelope) to 5 km/s for the outflow to increase the sensitivity of the observations.
We have selected a spectral average of 2 to reduce the data rate.

The central torus has a size 2" in radius. The warm region around the torus has a size of 3-4" and the outflow extends over 10". The selected angular resolution of 0.18" is a good compromise to fully characterize the warm gas around CRL2688. Extended emission is present in CO and we required an additional compact configuration to obtain larger spatial structures (outflows).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CRL2688: CCH N=3-2 HCCCN J=29-28 HCN J=3-2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Single point position with frequency setup covering the J=29-28 line of HCCCN in all vibrational states below 1000 cm-1. CCH N=3-2 and HCN J=3-2 will be also observed. CCH N=3-2 will trace directly the photodissociation region of acetylene in the envelope (innermost and external layers). HCN will provide the highest angular resolution view of the dense gas around the central object, the bipolar outflow and the central torus.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The expected line intensity in a beam of .18" is 3000-4000 times that observed with the 30m at the same frequency (beam 11"). Hence, brightness temperatures of several tens to hundreds K are expected with ALMA from the dense internal region of CRL2688 depending on the molecular transition. The longest spatial scales will correspond to those of the ground state of the molecules covered in the proposed band coverage.

The requested spectral resolution of 1 km/s will permit to resolve the different regions of the envelope of CRL2688 (outflow 100-400 km/s, warm expanding envelope 10-40 km/s, and the lines from the central torus region 5-10 km/s). Spectral averaging can not performed at data acquistion without degrading the science goals related to the study of the torus. For the other regions of the envelope the data will be averaged after processing to a resolution of 2 km/s (warm expanding envelope) to 5 km/s for the outflow to increase the sensitivity of the observations.
We have selected a spectral average of 2 to reduce the data rate.

The central torus has a size 2" in radius. The warm region around the torus has a size of 3-4" and the outflow extends over 10". The selected angular resolution of 0.18" is a good compromise to fully characterize the warm gas around CRL2688.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to observe two carbon-rich protoplanetary nebulae (PPNe), CRL 618 and CRL 2688, to investigate the physical and chemical conditions that lead to complex hydrocarbon chemistry in the circumstellar environment of evolved stars after the AGB phase. These two transition objects are characterized by a different temperature, hence UV field, of the central star. Polyacetylenes and cyanopolyynes have been detected in both sources but benzene, the first aromatic ring, is only seen in CRL 618. Emission from carbon dust of mixed aromatic/aliphatic composition is only seen in CRL 2688. For both molecules and grains, UV-processing was invoked as a key process in driving the chemical evolution. We aim to reconcile these observational facts and get new insights into the gas and dust chemistry. The physical and chemical conditions are retrieved from studying HCCCN, CCH, HCN, CN, and CO. For CRL 618 we also observe HCO+ and a recombination line of Hydrogen to characterise its compact photodissociation region (PDR). Only with ALMA can we accurately probe the densest, smallest regions (at scales of 0.2 to ~1") where the most active chemistry is expected.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2013.1.00664.S, From hydrocarbons to dust in Protoplanetary nebulae, PI: C. Joblin -- Ranked B

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institut de Recherche en Astrophysique et Planetologie
